fields.label_text:
5, 6
HARRY RANDALL’S MAKE-UP CASE

This is a fine example of a 19th-century travelling dressing case. Harry Randall was a comedy actor, famous for his character songs and pantomimes. The quality of the box is a mark of Randall’s status as a performer. The music sheet cover depicts Randall in the costume and make-up he wore to perform a popular song.

Make-up box
1840–60
Brass, glass, leather, mother-of-pearl, silver, steel, velvet and wood
Given by Valerie Appleton
Museum no. S.135:1 to 27–2004

Music sheet cover for a song performed by Harry Randall
About 1900
Printed paper
Harry R. Beard Collection, given by Isobel Beard
Museum no. S.145:2-1989

fields.descriptive_line: Dressing case used as a make-up box by the music hall performer Harry Randall. Made by J.J. Mechi, London, c.1850.
fields.physical_description:
Wooden dressing case with inlaid brass edging to the lid and sides, lock surround and lock, hinges and handle, the base covered in green baize or felt.  The lid of the box is lined with ruched and padded blue velvet, around which there is a dark blue leather border stamped with a gilt foliate pattern. The velvet covered lid panel can be hinged outwards but not removed. The box contains a removable wooden tray divided into six compartments, three of the compartments lined with blue leather; two with pads of blue velvet and one without lining but with a wooden lid with a silver knob.The tray contains a wooden lidded compartment, two small round glass jars with silver lids, a long glass tray with a pierced and chased silver lid and a compartment with indentations for tweezers, a corkscrew, a button hook, an awl, manicure scissors and a nail file.  The manicure cissors and one of the tweezers were obviously replacement items since they do not fit into the indentations and the tweezers have a different and more decorative mothert of pearl handle. The main body of the dressing case has four deep compartments, three containing silver-lidded jars, and one empty with a wooden lid with a silver knob, similar to the wooden lid in the tray but not the same size.
[Tray] Wooden removable tray made to fit in the dressing case, with two small metal handles. The tray is divided into six compartments, 3 lined with leather and two containing blue velvet pads, one removable which has indents to support an awl, two tweezers, a nail file, scissors, a button-hook and a corkscrew.  One unlined compartment has a wooden lid with a silver-plated knob.
[Lid] Wooden lid with silver-plated knob made to fit the unlined compartment of the removable tray from the dressing case.  A thin decorative gold line runs around the box 5cms from the edges.
[Pad] Removable pad from a tray in a dressing case.  The pad is covered with dark blue velvet and made with indentations to support an awl, two tweexers, a nail file, scissors, a button hook and a corkscrew.  The pad lifts off to reveal a compartment below lined with blue moiré silk.
[Lid] Wooden lid bordered with a thin gold line and with a silver knob.  Made as a component of the tray in the wooden dressing case used as a make-up box by Harry Randall.
[Tweezers] Metal tweezers with a plain, round ended mother of pearl handle.
[Cork screw] Steel corkscrew with a plain round ended mother of pearl handle.
[Button hook] Steel button hook with a plain round ended mother of pearl handle.
[Scissors] Manicure scissors
[Nail file] Nail file with broken file and a plain round ended mother of pearl handle
[Tweezers] Tweezers with steel tweezers and a mother of pearl handle, the end carved in decorative and stylised foliate shape.
[Awl] Stainless steel awl with a plain round ended mother of pearl handle
[Jar] Small round glass pot or jar composed of ten flat panels, the bottom featuring an etched floral or sunburst decorative shape with fifteen points
[Lid] Silver lid to small glass jar or pot
[Dish] Oblong glass tray, the base featuring a decorative floral or sunburst pattern
[Lid] Pierced and chased silver lid to oblong class tray
[Bottle] Square glass bottle with rounded shoulders
[Lid] Silver lid or cap bottle which has a glass stopper
[Bottle] Square glass bottle with rounded shoulders
[Stopper] Glass stopper to bottle
[Lid] Silver lid or cap of  bottle which also has a glass stopper
[Jar] Cylindrical glass jar whose sides are composed from 16 panels of flat glass, the base featuring a flower of decorative sunburst pattern with fifteen points.
[Lid] Silver lid to cylindrical glass jar
[Stopper] Glass stopper to bottle
[Jar] Small round glass pot or jar composed of ten flat panels, the bottom featuring an etched floral or sunburst decorative shape with fifteen points
[Lid] Silver lid or cap to jar which has a glass stopper
[Key] White metal key with a flattened oval head without any metal in the centre.  Used to secure the lockable lid of the dressing case.

fields.marks:
'No.4 LEADENHALL ST. LONDON. J.J.MECHI.  To prevent fraudulent imitations signs all his articles thus without which NONE ARE GENIUNE.'
 'J.J.Mechi'
fields.public_access_description:
This dressing case is a good example of a 19th century travelling dressing case, and was used by the leading music hall comic and pantomime dame Harry Randall (1860-1932) as a make-up box.  The fine quality of the box and its fittings is a mark of the status that Randall reached as a performer, but  it was the only personal possession of Harry Randall's that was preserved by his family. 

Randall's first professional appearance was in 1884 at Deacon's Music Hall in Islington. Like his good friend Dan Leno, Randall became known for his comedy character songs and his pantomime dames, several of which he performed in pantomimes with Leno. His songs were full of topical jokes and satire, and his characters frequently broke off from singing to launch into a stream of comic patter. He wrote several songs in the form of 'advice' to the audience, such as the one he wrote about the dangers of drinking.  Harry Randall was in the first Royal Variety Performance at the Palace Theatre in 1912, and he became so well known that his name was used in the rhyming slang for 'candles' which became known as 'Harry Randalls', or simply 'Harrys!'
fields.exhibition_history: Theatre and  Performance (Victoria and Albert Museum, Galleries 103 -106 01/01/2009-31/12/2009)
fields.bibliography: The Performer, 21 June 1906, advertisement of engagement. HARRY RANDALL Comedian Address: ECCENTRIC CLUB
fields.credit: Given by the family of John W. Brown
fields.history_note:
The donor, a relative by marriage to Harry Randall, wrote: "I am the current custodian of his travelling box in which he kept his make-up.  It has been passed down through the family originating from his sister in law Mrs Annie (Nancy) Randall who was married to Alf Randall, Harry's brother.  She had everything belonging to Harry Randall, his make-up box, his scrap book, his chair and his sheet music.

After my Great Aunt Nancy died everything of Harry's was thrown out, except his make-up box which my father's sister kept.  At this time it still had his original make in on the jars but when my father's sister died and I became the new owner of the box, all the make-up had been washed out by my aunt, unfortunately."
